articles.headline: Universal Conquers the Box Office, Without a Superhero
articles.snippet: The studio has a string of nine hits out of its last 10 releases with a range of nonsuperhero films, including “Straight Outta Compton,” “Jurassic World” and “Minions.”
articles.abstract: The studio has a string of nine hits out of its last 10 releases with a range of nonsuperhero films, including “Straight Outta Compton,” “Jurassic World” and “Minions.”

articles.headline: Investors Hope to Ride Swell of SoulCycle Fever in Coming I.P.O.
articles.snippet: Boutique fitness centers that cater to those willing to pay more for a good sweat are on the rise, and wealthy backers are betting this market is more than a craze.
articles.abstract: Boutique fitness centers that cater to those willing to pay more for a good sweat are on the rise, and wealthy backers are betting this market is more than a craze.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early on a summer morning in Manhattan’s Upper East Side, dozens of mostly young, svelte women file into a quiet, candlelit studio where they mount gleaming stationary bikes. Soft clicks can be heard as they fasten their shoes to the pedals.

articles.headline: Cadillac Has New Boss, New Address and Big Plans
articles.snippet: Cadillac, which has moved to Manhattan, used aggressive design and performance to put its old image in the past, but that comeback has since stalled.
articles.abstract: Cadillac, which has moved to Manhattan, used aggressive design and performance to put its old image in the past, but that comeback has since stalled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can a South African-born former Audi executive, who recently spurned Japanese masters in Hong Kong, lead a Detroit luxury brand back to greatness — and from a new base in Manhattan?

articles.headline: 2 Graduating Rangers, Aware of Their Burden
articles.snippet: Two Army Ranger graduates are set to break new ground in the military as the Pentagon prepares to decide which combat positions should be opened to women.
articles.abstract: Two Army Ranger graduates are set to break new ground in the military as the Pentagon prepares to decide which combat positions should be opened to women.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga. — First Lt. Shaye Haver, an Apache attack helicopter pilot who on Friday will be one of the first women to graduate from the Army’s elite Ranger School, wants to remain an aviator. But she takes away weighty lessons from her grueling Ranger training: “Your mind can take a whole lot more than your body,” she said.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: China Woes Send Stocks Into Tailspin
articles.snippet: Plummeting stock markets worldwide signal that investors have not gotten over the shock of China’s devaluation last week.
articles.abstract: Plummeting stock markets worldwide signal that investors have not gotten over the shock of China’s devaluation last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock markets around the world plummeted on Thursday, signaling that investors have not gotten over the shock of China’s devaluation last week and remain nervous about the health of the global economy.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Draws Big Crowds to His ‘Political Revolution’
articles.snippet: The words are full of passion, but the senator and his followers speak to an angry vision of a broken system that requires fundamental change.
articles.abstract: The words are full of passion, but the senator and his followers speak to an angry vision of a broken system that requires fundamental change.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBUQUE, Iowa — As 1,800 mad-as-hell supporters jumped out of their seats and pumped their fists last Sunday, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont delivered the message they had come to hear.

articles.headline: Stocks Plunge Sharply for a Second Day on Wall Street
articles.snippet: The downturn threatens to end one of the longest bull runs in the history of the United States stock market.
articles.abstract: The downturn threatens to end one of the longest bull runs in the history of the United States stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock prices around the world continued to plunge on Friday, threatening to end one of the longest bull runs in the history of the United States stock market.

articles.headline: As Another Club Closes, Sunset Strip’s Evolution Continues
articles.snippet: New construction looms over the famous nightclubs that have long defined a stretch of Sunset Boulevard in West Hollywood, a transformation many find jarring.
articles.abstract: New construction looms over the famous nightclubs that have long defined a stretch of Sunset Boulevard in West Hollywood, a transformation many find jarring.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — The House of Blues stood by the Sunset Strip for 21 years strong, another rock ’n’ roll outpost on a curvy boulevard renowned for its music, comedy, celebrity, glamour and a bit of sleaze. But this month the club’s run came to an end, announced with a “Thank you, L.A.!” message on its billboard and workers carting out computer screens and folding chairs. The bulldozers — and a new high-rise luxury hotel-condominium — are on the way.

articles.headline: Iran Prepares to Lure Foreign Investors After Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: Iranian officials have gone out of their way to emphasize that once sanctions are lifted, nothing stands in the way of foreigners snapping up assets.
articles.abstract: Iranian officials have gone out of their way to emphasize that once sanctions are lifted, nothing stands in the way of foreigners snapping up assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZARRINABAD, Iran — When Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps took over the nation’s telecommunications monopoly in 2009, the move was denounced as another dark step in the hard-line military group’s seizure of the levers of power.

articles.headline: As Workers Delay Retirement, Some Bosses Become More Flexible
articles.snippet: More employers are introducing flexibility into their schedules or allowing employees to step slowly out of the work force with phased retirement.
articles.abstract: More employers are introducing flexibility into their schedules or allowing employees to step slowly out of the work force with phased retirement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corliss Fanjoy is turning 65 this year, but she is not ready for retirement. And at a small handbag maker in Maine, where Mrs. Fanjoy spends her working hours cutting intricate patterns in leather, she is not alone.

articles.headline: Getting Workaholics to Stop and Recharge
articles.snippet: Americans are taking less time off than ever, studies find, but nonstop workers who find ways to decompress can enjoy physical and mental benefits.
articles.abstract: Americans are taking less time off than ever, studies find, but nonstop workers who find ways to decompress can enjoy physical and mental benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anthony Hitt, chief executive of Engel & Völkers North America, a luxury property company, spends at least one week each quarter at his home in Maui, Hawaii. At this point, three years into the top job, he said he talks to his top lieutenants only 15 minutes a day when he’s there. The rest of the time he reads, practices yoga, rides his bicycle or otherwise tries to disconnect from the responsibilities of his job.

articles.headline: Vague Disclosures by Highflying Mutual Funds May Put Investors in Peril
articles.snippet: Leveraged loans, a kind of obligation held by floating-rate income funds, carry risks that are often not fully disclosed to investors.
articles.abstract: Leveraged loans, a kind of obligation held by floating-rate income funds, carry risks that are often not fully disclosed to investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Desperate for richer yields on their portfolios, individual investors have thronged in recent years to mutual funds promising higher-than-usual income. The question is: Do these investors understand the higher-than-usual risks involved?

articles.headline: This Week’s Market Sell-Off May Not Be Such a Bad Thing
articles.snippet: A remarkable run-up in stock prices probably needed a breather at a time when a range of markets had been starting to look a little bubbly.
articles.abstract: A remarkable run-up in stock prices probably needed a breather at a time when a range of markets had been starting to look a little bubbly.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a frantic week on Wall Street and in other financial centers, with stocks and other risky assets experiencing their worst week in years.
